comments.commentBody:
"In Germany, employees' premiums are a percentage of their incomes, so low-wage workers simply pay rock-bottom insurance rates.

The sickness funds are Germany's version of a “public” health insurance system, and it covers nearly everyone. But a small segment (13 percent) of the population, generally the very wealthy, can opt-out and instead go with the private Krankenversicherung, which follows rules more similar the pre-Obamacare U.S. individual insurance market. ... All things considered, it’s good to be a sick German. There are no network limitations, so people can see any doctor they want. There are no deductibles, so Germans have no fear of spending hundreds before their insurance ever kicks in."

"Prices for procedures there are lower and more uniform because doctors’ associations negotiate their fees directly with all of the sickness funds in each state. That's part of the reason why an appendectomy costs $3,093 in Germany, but $13,000 in the U.S.

“In Germany, there is a uniform fee schedule for all physicians that work under the social code,” Schlette said. “There’s a huge catalogue where they determine meticulously how much is billed for each procedure. That’s like the Bible.”
...
Maryland, for example, has been regulating how much all of the state’s hospitals can charge since 1977. A 2009 study published in Health Affairs found that we would have saved $2 trillion ... (at the same growth rate)."

Why is there a bust? Because we have a boom and bust economy. Booms are always followed by busts, and then by another boom.

It isn't the budget balance, it is deeper in the structure of the boom and bust cycle.
Nobody's perfect.
Don't forget the starting point, destroying the Native Americans and taking their land to then build on it w slave labor.

America has never been above violating the rights of others. This nation's economic foundations were built upon the blood and sweat of black slaves. In the 20th century, we imprisoned thousands of Japanese citizens. The opening decade of the, once gloriously anticipated, 21st century was marked by the slaughter of 300,000 Iraqi and Afghani citizens because "someone" had to pay for the intellence lapse that allowed 9/11 to happen. Our great and powerful Intelligence gathering agency, made to look so foolish after 9/11 and the Iraq war, was turned on American citizens. Our head of intellegence, James Clapper, lied to congress and yet manages to hold that post. Now we see an innocent man, who has lost 14 years of his life for nothing, given a brief hearing before he is returned to America's gulag. And yet America continues to label itself as "exceptional."

The only thing that is truly exceptional about America, is the sheer level of hypocrisy with which we hold our noses in the air as we criticize the barbarism of the nation's we vanquish, the millions we imprison during our self-riteous "War on Drugs," and the international conventions we violate with things like indefinite imprisonment without charge.

"In any event, it is clear Bush & Co. tried to find a middle ground with waterboarding--something more than what would be considered lawful to inflict on a U.S. citizen or within the territory of the U.S. but something much more defensible than what our enemies in this war regularly engage in (burning alive, live decapitation, etc.). "
No, wrong. The Constitution plainly describes treaties ratified with the advice and consent of 2/3 of the Senate as "the supreme law of the land." That roster of treaties includes the Geneva Conventions and the International Convention Against Torture, making waterboarding (which we successfully prosecuted as a capital war crime) completely out of bounds. And neither the provisions of those treaties, nor the bill of rights' requirements of due process, speedy trial and freedom from cruel and unusual punshment specify in any way that those protections apply only to US citizens or on US soil. In fact, the bill of rights provisions only say what the government may not do, with no caveats whatsoever. You parrot failing rationalizations used by the Junior Bush Reign of Error. And how many wrongs make a right, in comparison to the enemy. Why the military was against what the CIA overenthusiastically embraced is because what we do to others could easily be visited upon captured soldiers. Sir, we HANGED Japanese officers who ordered the waterboarding of our soldiers in WWII. It is sheer hypocrisy to try to justify its use.
Obama has had seven years to release this guy.
Obama has been holding him and this administration held the hearing.

Bush and Cheney are two of the only reasons you haven't been consumed by this disease called Islamic Jihad. We need to continue to kill it wherever it is found. This man can never be set free, Your memories are far too short.
Bush/Cheney are public enemies, and are traitors to our nation.  They should be on trial, rather than Mr. Zubaydah.

Our laws come from our Constitution and follow us no matter where we are. That this happens by our hands binds those actions to the American people, and will lead to the torture of our armed services personnel. We have chosen to lead in sanctioned torture. Anyone surprised by other states following our lead underestimates the stature and the example of the United States worldwide.

Hey Joe, it was due to cowardly Republicant intransigence that Gitmo remains open. Not even the Supermax prison in CO assuages the untrammeled fear of the Republicants in refusing to bring Gitmo detainees onto American soil.
EinT, that would be zero.
It has never meant anything except self-content, self-excuse and self-aggrandizement.

During the torture era, a common response to the use of torture by our government was "They are guilty of attacking us so they deserve it." Others responded "Guilty according to whom?" and "It doesn't matter: Torture is illegal and immoral."

The first group attacked the second group as being weak and naive. They even threw around the term "treason" because they viewed the second group not as siding with principle and the rule of law, but with the enemy instead.

It used to be a high point of pride among Americans that we did not torture. Even when we faced TRUE existential threats during WWII and the Cold War, we did not abandon this principle. It gave us power through moral standing, and among other things yielded us many talented immigrants who viewed our society as humane.

As traumatic as 9/11 was, the threat was never existential. Al Qaeda was the enemy, not Germany, Japan, and Italy combined. Relative to those countries, the threat from Al Qaeda was infinitesimal.

This story made me sick. It made me sick because of the unspeakable agony delivered to Mr. Zubaydah and others in our names. But it also made me sick because of the ease at which most Americans were happy to abandon the "no torture" principle in the face of a relatively small threat.

I really wonder what the term "American Exceptionalism" means any more when so many Americans are willing to so easily abandon bedrock principles because of their own cowardice.

. Let's stop this mistake before we lose our souls and not remembering who we are.

50 years too late
that happened in vietnam

If you want to go back to Vietnam- how about the War of 1812? Mexican-American War?

It is never too late to rectify a mistake. It is not like never making the mistake or rectifying it immediately after the mistake was made. But it is something. How about trying to make Abu Zubaydah's life whole again?

What have we become? Are we Chinese, Russians or the Saudis? Has the U.S. government become a government that once our security is at risk, we can throw the Bill of Rights out of the window?

What evidence do we have against Abu Zubaydah? Little if not none. Let's stop this mistake before we lose our souls and not remembering who we are.
Yep, upgraded signalling ultimately allows the trains to run closer together, hence, more frequently.

I went to high school in NYC in the 60's and many of the trains had pairs of cras that were connected.  You could indeed ride in the connector area and there were ceramic-like handles for you to hold onto during the bumps and curves.  Extending the idea to entire trains just makes sense.  It allows for more people in the same train.  It also allows for movement away from threats, something that cannot happen when you have the end doors of the cars locked.

Yes! We're the exception.

And London has caught our bad habit of charging subway by distance zones. It's really expensive.

I will make sure your comments are directed to the families of the 158 Canadian soldiers who died fighting on the front lines in southern Afghanistan often directly alongside American military personnel AND four of whom who were killed by American pilots in a tragic friendly fire incident early on in the mission.

Incidentally, don't blame other countries for your problems because you ignored the words of Eisenhower "beware the military/industrial complex". Fighting endless wars ultimately bankrupts empires even your beloved America.

More than once I've needed to move from one car to another to avoid someone who appeared dangerously agitated (e.g., mumbling curses to self while pacing up and down the car and throwing air punches). I would feel less safe in an open train in NYC - though maybe not in Toronto.

Ultimately, new street cars have been slow in arriving from the manufacturer with some already in service, however, when they all finally arrive to replace the existing ones they will hold 3 times the passengers of a bus and have A/C.  hence, less of them will be required.
It seems you last checked around 1960.
Well, from what I understand the Mayor often takes the subway to work.

Ultimately, to one degree or another, the countries under discussion have determined that public transit is an integral part of a successful urban environment and they are willing to spend the money to keep it that way. Unfortunately, in recent years in America, bailing out banks, providing subsidies and tax breaks to billionaires and spending trillions fighting endless wars seems to have a considerably higher priority than spending money improving infrastructure and and the lives of everyday people.

In Toronto, on wider streets and along the lines of LRT systems, dedicated tracks have been built in which the streetcars, especially the newer designed models, don't interfere with the traffic.  They also have THREE times the capacity of a bus.
The newer designed streetcars have THREE times the capacity of a bus!

Get the antitrust people to tell this company to provide technology for another competing plant to make the EpiPen; sort of a reverse merger. If they refuse the government should take control of the factory by immanent domain. When the lives of the people are at stake this is justified.

Absolute delight !
A treat to go trough the slide show. Awakes so many different emotions and questions. This is what a true artist does with a camera in hands.

I don't see how the need to have more than one EpiPen available is the result of Big Pharma's influence.  It does no good to have one pen at home when the patient is somewhere other than home while suffering from an allergic reaction.  This is pure greed on the part of Big Pharma yes, but in terms of price, not in terms of need.

I google/ fact checked, found the Burke reference, chose not to cite it: Orwell has the public credit, - cf "Man Who Shot Liberty Valance" - 'when the facts conflict with the myth, print the myth'

I've read Burmese Days, nothing there about bureaucracy, only cloistered beleaguered expats drunk, self-importantly exclusive, to their ruination, by a local pol, roman a clef, disguised characters (libel laws), deciphered years later

Orwell was a recovered Leftist

- also Ayn Rand's Atlas dystopia, -- Obama-nation is perfectly described, even with her many literary faults

Obama is Commander in Chief, military would have to mutiny to refuse a direct order, mutiny is rare in US history and would not be over this, nor is this - Gitmo - a Nuremberg matter, following orders

As for immoral, Obama has had eight years of presidential power, his Teflon as is thick and pure as ever, -- anything that goes wrong is somebody ease's fault

An article today talked about Donald and psychopathy, one aspect is externalizing fault,

Obama is The Man

Not My Fault

BUT lutes for peace? go for it
